# This lecture will introduce the material properties *stress* and *strain*

# We will start with the important definitions

## Stress {transition="fade"}

**Stress** is a measure of the *force per unit area*.

::: {.fragment .fade-in}
This can also be expressed as a mathematical equation:

```{=tex}
\begin{gather*}
Stress = \frac{Force}{Area}
\end{gather*}
```
:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in}
```{=tex}
\begin{gather*}
Stress~(N/m^2) = \frac{Force~(N)}{Area~(m^2)}
\end{gather*}
```
:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in}
```{=tex}
\begin{gather*}
\sigma = \frac{F}{A}
\end{gather*}
```
:::

## Strain

**Strain** is the change in length of a material divided by its original length.

::: {.fragment .fade-in}
```{=tex}
\begin{gather*}
Strain = \frac{Change~in~length}{Original~length}
\end{gather*}
```
:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in}
```{=tex}
\begin{gather*}
Strain~(no~units) = \frac{Change~in~length~(m)}{Original~length~(m)}
\end{gather*}
```
:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in}
```{=tex}
\begin{gather*}
\epsilon = \frac{\delta l}{L}
\end{gather*}
```
:::

## Young's modulus

**Young's modulus** is stress divided by strain.

::: {.fragment .fade-in}
```{=tex}
\begin{gather*}
Young's~modulus = \frac{Stress}{Strain}
\end{gather*}
```
:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in}
```{=tex}
\begin{gather*}
E = \frac{\sigma}{\epsilon}
\end{gather*}
```
:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in}
Consider the mnemonic *FLEA* to help you get the formula the right way round: 

**F**orce times original **L**ength, divided by **E**xtension times **A**rea
:::

## Yield point

The transition between elastic and plastic deformation. Defined at an arbitrary amount of strain (usually 0.2%).

![](sscurve2.svg){.absolute top="100" left="200" height="700"}

# What happens if we unload the material after it has been plastically deformed?

## Unloading curve

The material unloads along the blue dashed line and remains permanently deformed.
